pgTitle: List of demolished places of worship in West Sussex

rows.text: This stood on a road (Dorset Gardens) which has also been lost to redevelopment. It was in religious use only until 1869, after which it had many functions including a theatre.

At a cost of £85, and with the support of Rev. F.H.D. Smythe (later an Archdeacon of Lewes), a small hut used as a wartime soldiers' church "on the [Sussex] coast" was moved to the hamlet of Cinder Hill in Horsted Keynes parish in 1919. A pre-existing Sunday school moved in, and the building was used intermittently for worship as well.

Durrington's Roman Catholic parish was constituted in 1927. The first chapel, on Cotswold Road, was erected in 1938. It closed and was demolished when a replacement building was put up on Hayling Rise in 1966.

This small localised sect erected an iron building on Flansham Lane for their services, which were latterly held on Wednesdays. For a time in the 1930s it was shared with Methodists until they built their permanent church in 1939.
This chapel at the end of Chapel Road closed in the 1890s but still stood until the area was redeveloped for industry.
Apparently built to replace the old Congregational church yards (m) away, this survived in religious use only until 1947. After that it became a community hall until its demolition.
St Edward and St Louis Church
Commercial (Sergeant Pepper's Amusements and Snack Bar)

A red-brick chapel on the main road through Small Dole served the area's Baptists from 1880 until 1977, when it was closed and converted into the village hall. A new hall was built on another site after 1981, and the original building was demolished in 1983.
This Methodist church was founded in 1884 and had a capacity of 80. The red-brick building fell out of religious use in 1930.

This hall was used for Christian worship between 1903 and 1957. The two-storey Institute building, which had a three-window range and paired entrance porches, also had a reading room and other facilities. It later became a public library.
Originally a mission hall and latterly registered as a Free church, this had its worship registration cancelled on 9 December 1970.
This was registered as a Brethren meeting hall in 1892, five years after its construction. It stood at 12 Chapel Road for about 30 years, but was demolished after its closure in 1918.
